reviews.review_text: Now that i have reached 100 hours in Hoi4 i think its time to set right what so many steam 'reviewers' and mainly QQers have done wrong.  So, join me in this journey as i go through everything the game is offering and taking it apart, giving you an actual idea of what the game is about instead of reading a review of ppl with about 20 to 10 hrs gametime or less - because in this game it actually makes a difference.   Disclaimers: 0.) Havent done the tutorial since i come from Hoi3 and didnt think i needed it. Was right, but i hear its not really helpful for newbies tho :/ 0.1) very hard for me to stay in the review corner and not turn this into a guide, so if you feel this explains too much, let me know.  Table of Contents:  1.) UI, its what you usually see first when you launch your first match, pros and cons. 2.) National politics tab, where you set Bonuses to your Nation, and go down the focus tree. 3.) Research, obviously where you get Nukes and V2´s. 4.) Diplomacy, or Public relations as i like to call it. 5.) Trading, yeah have fun with that as germany -.- 6.) Construction, not to confuse with production, here you build factories, AAA, costal defences, and all the juicy stuff your provinces could ever need, even recources ;P 7.) Production, not to confuse for Construction, here you build tanks, aircraft, ships and infantry equipment. Everything a soldier could wish for. 8.) Recruting, this is where you actually train and deploy new units. 9.) Logistics, overview of what you have, need and produce. 10.) Gameplay, here i will talk about the actual gameplay and stuff that happens on the map. 12.) Overall Impression, final thoughts.    UI:   This is a combination of mixed feelings for me, because it throws new ppl into the cold water. Once you get your head around it, it is very intuitive and easy to understand and follow the developers logic with how and why they went with this. Tho i have to admit, my con in this is that the switching between the mapmodes in the bottom right corner (recources, resistance, supplies etc.) is a little bit enraging since the buttons are so genuisly tiny that you tend to hit the screens edge and end up in japan when youre fighting in the north see before you selected the supply mode. But i heard they are going to adress that in future patches (The way we know Paradox theyre likely to laugh diabolicly at that kind of misfortune as well...).    National Politics:  This is where you spend your political power on in the first 2 years of any game, you equip your nation with all sorts of bonuses by setting politicians or laws that reach into every aspect of the game, even combat.  For me, this was one of the easier features to understand and it is indeed very straight forward and self explanatory.  As well as that, you set national focuses wich bring you on the path to war and greater power, for the most part. Depending on your nation - Superpowers like russia USA, UK or germany get a specific one for themselves while minors like Spain, Nepal or Luxembourg have to share the same one - you have different objectives that you can choose to go for. For germany that would obviously be the annexation of austria and the chech part of chechoslovakia, or in the Russian tree you have a lot of 'SEND PEEPOL TO GULAG!'    Research:  Now we come to a little bit more juicy stuff. When it comes to research you get a metric button of choices at the start of a game and during earlygame, a lot of catching up during midgame, and a mixture of 'so what the ♥♥♥♥ am i going to do with myself now' and 'YAY' when you finished all your tech trees in late and endgame.  Overall the techs explain themselves very well and are for the time they are set in EXCLUDING THE MODERN TANKS (E-50, Challanger & Co.) very well placed. By wich i mean it all makes sense. But you reach lategame tanks to quickly. In 60% of my matches as germany i could skip Panthers and Panzer 4´s and go straight for the E-50. Wich is brilliant btw.    Diplomacy:    Ahhh yes, the most useless thing in any hearts of Iron game because your Hitlerin and Blitzkriegin your way to World dominance anyway and you know you will :D  Im kidding... now with Hoi4 you can actually do stuff with it! Make USA into Nazi country and call themselves 'Free American Reich'? CHECK! Make france turn communist, leave the allies and join up with Russia in comintern? CHECK!  Wanna do cool stuff like that? Well here is where.  Also i like how war declerations are performed now, gives it a little more strategic and realistic feeling to have public denounciation of *coughdenmark* uhm i mean various countries going on before stepping on them *cough* it.    Trading:   Now, here are the biggest strengths and weaknesses of nations coming together. Germany´s lack of everthing, Uk´s Overflow in everything but steel. USA´s ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amounts of Oil. This tab, including all the recources that the game has (i know this is not a guide but i think for ppl that want to buy the game by any chance would be helped if they knew this); Oil, Rubber, Tungsten, Steel, Aluminium and Chromium; is very well designed and intertwined with the rest of the game in my opinion. So far i couldnt find anything bad about it.    Construction:   Here, we start to get a little more strategic, Youll need Civillian factories to repair bomb, combat and resistance fighter damage, and to build new stuff like more factories, more factories or more factories. (In a way this is me both actually telling the truth and joking at the same time)   I have to be honest with you, you could go for nothing but factories but if you did that you wouldnt be very happy, yes a good amount of factories - military or civillian - is indeed neccessary but you need other stuff as well, your provincal anti air guns will be useless if you dont build radar and research good encryption, your trooops will run out of supplies when you fight without infrastructure in russia, etc. All that sort of stuff needs to be sorted or you will make it more difficult on yourself.    Production:   I really dont know what to to this. Whenever i meet someone new to Hoi4 and they run into Production, theyre always like, HELP!!!!!!!  And then it takes me 2 Minutes or less to explain what it what and they theyre saying, ah okay this is actually pretty easy...   Important to note here is that all the equipment you produce gets AUTOMATICLY transfered into eighter your divisions on the field, or if they are all fully equipped into storage. Production is 100% passive and in the background, if you produce everything you need then there is nothing you have to worry about from there on out. If Equipment is still missing build more. The Logistics tab helps a lot with that but were not quite there.  There is one little thing that i have to ad for a personal con, and thats when you open up the list of things you can open up a new line with, there should be an option for every vehicle to be turned off and on again so you dont have to see them. Because the longer a match gets, the more of a scrollfest it becomes. very annoing.     Recruiting:  Now here is where ppl get lost easily, because you dont only tell the game to recruit whats there, you also have to look at your division templates and change them to your needs. And you HAVE to do that. You can not expect to win against france if one of your division has 5k men full strength.   All in all i am pleased with how Paradox set this up, it is all very logical and easy once you understood it. Getting there is mostly the issue but when you buy a paradox game you sign up for this.    I will now have to stop because im running out of letters.............. NOT AMUSED   Well i guess you get the point i love the game and everyone should.   Goodbuy!

As much as I love the Hearts of Iron series and almost every Paradox game I cannot recommend this to anyone in its current state. The game compared to prior versions of Hearts of Iron, or many Paradox grand strategy games, has been simplifed to the point where it is no longer fun or interesting. It has none of the replayabily of other titles like Crusader Kings, EU, or Victoria 2. However, replayabilty is just one major problem among many.  The biggest problem is the AI, which is probably the worst I have ever seen in a game like this in ages. It cannot manage its own forces, build anything, and generally just spits out waves of infanty and fighters. The AI cannot handle what they want it to do, which includes basic production of war goods. This game was delayed for over a year and this is what they thought of as releasable, which is nothing more than a paid alpha.   While the AI is bad, the most damning thing is the design decisions made in this game. The UI is a mess, constantly clicking through multiple widows to seach for the most basic info. Just to find out the size of your army is hidden in a non-descript number behind a force summary. Information is hard to come by and often just never presented to you until after you notice a huge disaster.   This games economic content in its current state is a huge disaster of its own. It has none of the depth or fun of Darkest Hour, which game players extreme amounts of choices and options. Everything is based off of resources and basically two factory types: civilian and military. All of which the AI can't manange. There is no comprehensive diplomacy or espionage system, which I assume was but for a paid DLC later.   Ultimately, this game is a cash grab. Ton's of content missing and bad design decisions that they pass to the modding community to fix and add content for. Everything else will be behind pay walls of DLC which will undoubtably have packs for indvidual countries and content that was just considered part of the game in previous versions.

I'm a big fan of the series but they dumbed down almost every element of the game (compared to HOI 3&2). This may makes the game more accessible but it ruins all of the joy and long term motivation of the game.  The new game should allways have more (and better working) features than the predecessor, not less!  Main Issues are: -Bad, very, very bad AI. How come the AI has become worse than in the previous games?! The Lines of AI-generals look like swiss cheese and as long as they feel superior in numbers they keep attacking in the most self-destructing ways, without any regard for there losses and the value of the gained position. And now you have to rely on this stupid AI, because micromanagment has become all messed up. -Same goes for diplomatic AI - when soviets can stroll trough axis territory (depsite beeing on the brink of war with them) and capture south africa from the allies you start wondering why they delayed this game for a year. How bad can it have been before? -No more support attacks, no more planed arrivals or sheduled attack times for multiple divisions. the manual stategic movement and shipment of troops is completly messed up. -The trading system is a warcrime! Why must i buy 8 pcs when i only need one? And why can't even isolated dictatorships decided what they want to export to the world market, and tho whom? What was wrong with the old trading system? -No more sending air or battleship support to a single important fight - now you have to order them to ridiculously big regions and loose all oversight.  -For ground forces you have no chance to count your losses and compare them to the losses of your enemies after a battle ends. Ever heard of the term 'war of attrition', Paradox? What happened to all the statisitcs you could get in the previous games? -The new map sure looks nice but without terrain and weather filters it is useless for placing and moving your troops, this takes the rest of joy out of micromanagment. -Missing or broken supply-system for fleets and air wings (fleets can move and fight for years despite beeing cut off from friendly harbours)  The few improvments: -the new production and equipment system (the only thing that became more complex compared to the older games) -they added peace conferences like in Europa Universalis -The Focus tree system is very helpfull in customising your nation -you can now stage armed coups in any other country  In Grand Strategy I do not need fancy toyplanes flying over my map - Give me a working AI!! I recomend you wait untill they fix this game - as allways - with their countless DLCs and then buy a hopefully playable gold-edition.

Don't be daunted.   Those were three words I used to two friends who were considering playing Hearts of Iron 4.   It looks like a bunch of reading and dull mathematics, but once you open the game, and pick your country to play as (which I must mention can be any in the world) - that country is yours. And there's work to do.   Do you play as Nazi Germany, and fulfill Hitler's quest for world domination, or do you play as Nazi Germany and turn it Communist? Or Democratic? It's all possible in this game. The ultimate 'What if' scenario creator, and it's at your fingertips on a global scale.   I won't pretend that this game doesn't need some serious time, but damn is it worth it. Even the stock game, you can easily waste hours ensuring your economy is perfect, researching teschnology of the time, and 'national focuses' - which can either be historically accurate or a new direction you want to go with your little piece of land in the world.   Hearts of Iron can be as complicated or as simple as you want it to be. The HUGE community for modding the game transform the game in ways you can't imagine, so regardless of whether or not you're the 'strategy' type of gamer, Hearts of Iron has something to offer; and it may actually drag you into the bottomless pit of 'What if?'

Wonderful game and aguably the most solid title Paradox Interactive has ever launched.   Although it's being criticized, I feel that the switch to a more sandbox and  slightly  less railed WWII experience provides both historical grognards and world war microbebies a chance to live out their strategic dreams.  Come on, Neo-Ottoman Empire? That's friggin' awesome.  However, for all of the progress made in the field of accessibility and player inclusiveness we still have a ways to go. I say this for the thousands of people who are looking at HOI4 or have purchased HOI4 with no experience with Paradox grand strategy games. The Italy tutorial, while better than the one included in HOI3, lacks serious depth. If a newcomer were to hop in and play only the tutorial, then pick a major power, they would be screwed.  A very small nitpick and I understand that in a sense, I'm trying to have my cake and eat it too. You can't have grand strategy without complexity but newcomers could use a little more information! They shouldn't have to rely on the wiki for basic info about game mechanics. (Like how to use your navies, something completely absent from the tutorial. Or how to increase the reinforcement limit of airwings so you can continue to fill them with the planes you're producing, or how to manage occupied territories and switch occupation methods, etc...)  I feel that for the in-game tutorial to be successful the player should be left with enough information to hop into the game as a major power and have some idea of what they're doing. The fact that the tutorial doesn't cover all types of warfare, land, sea, and air is just inexcusable. Make Jake's entire job working on tutorials with that sweet sweet glaswegian ASMR voice of his.  Either way, I love this game and see myself playing it for a loooong time to come.

Even as a sandbox experience I feel the game is lacking, many nations are not properly flushed out, the ai is rather dull, supply is ridiculous and never impacts your units, There is lack of a proper espionage system, and the battle planner, while a great idea, is awful to use.  They should return to a semi order of battle that allows you to draw individual arrows within a battle plan for your lower ranking generals under a field marshal commanding the entire army. You should also be able to draw battle lines and arrows through multiple countries even if you are not at war with all of them. The battle plan should be implemented in peices as you declare war on  other countries.  While I, myself played a decent amount of hoi 3, I realize that it too has many flaws. Although spending many hours into this game, the core is obviously broken. The main concern here is the AI. The AI is really weak in fighting wars. Countries declare wars on other countries while losing an already existing war, which is absurd. Germany is the prime example of this. If you build a WW1-like front, the AI relentlessly attacks your frontlines, depleting its manpower entirely in the progress. This way, I've managed to destroy the Soviet Union in separate sessions with France, Italy and Germany, and with ease. Then there are also the ridiculous naval invasions performed by the AI. These invasions are numerous and meaningless, many times not even targetting an actual port, resulting in the slow but steady death of the divisions involved because you only have to surround them.   Next to these serious AI issues, the late-game suffers in terms of performance. When superpowers emerge and manage their hundreds of divisions, the game begins to lag. Playing on the highest speed will feel like playing on the lowest speed. I've never encountered a game that performed so badly on my PC, which more than manages itself with performance-based games, such as Arma III, and even other Paradox games.  Finally, the resource system doesn't make any sense. The army size does not affect the amount of resources used, it only targets the production of war material. So if you have a respectable size of industry, you can create a gazillion tank without having to suffer serious supply difficulties, or an impediment on your future production lines.   These are my main concerns, but I haven't listed them all. Nevertheless, I managed to have some fun with HoI4, but currently it is way to easy and unbalanced. I also wonder how the mentioned issues passed through beta-testing. I would suggest hiring new people or keep an closer eye on the actual test progress. Next to Stellaris, this is probably Paradox's worst product yet.

Having spent over 100 hours on Hearts of Iron III, another few hundred most likely on the non-Steam edition I had before getting the complete pack, and other Paradox games on top of that, I'd call Hearts of Iron IV a big disappointment. The game has plenty of potential and good things in it, but all of it is let down by some flaws and lack of depth.  -Battle-planner. It's something you don't have to use, many surely point this out. But it gives you a slight edge with the plan bonus and most of all, does the work for you. But if you're intent on using -and- actually playing at the same time, it tends to override your commands and making delicate plans, which I've already made up in my mind, is rather hard to do and annoying. It's not a good addition at all, instead people should devise their own tactics and respond to the tactical situations as they develop, not letting the AI do it. That's a big con.  -Armies. Now they're big, one front might be led by a single field marshal who can command an unlimited amount of divisions, in addition to a few dedicated -armies- for armour and possibly other special troops you might have. Having individual division, corps, army, army group and theatre commanders brought much depth and detail into the game, letting your special elite divisions develop more (with their commander), rather than having it all bunched to a few guys whom you'll use throughout the game. The command structure is gone, and with it the old supply system. Now if you're lacking supplies, your front suddenly gets locked down instead of letting the situation worsen over time and develop. But oh wait, there's no fuel. Unlimited fuel for Finnish armour.  -Resources and tech. The last point over there brings us to this topic; now it's possible to get a very developed army with nuclear weapons and rockets whilst playing a third world country. Other than that, the research is very simple and ends in ~1945, thus not giving much advantages for the great powers which had their cutting edge tech (or loads of men to spare, hoh). You can also produce everything you desire whilst having no resources, albeit at a much slower rate. And you cannot stockpile your resources either, instead they'll have to be traded, in addition to your RAD troops deciding to call it a halt whilst they're needed to haul rubber from Indonesia.  -AI issues, which seem to concern many other people. The AI hasn't really offered much of a challenge, the only thing that held of my blitzkrieg for France was RAF's air superiority, whilst for Brazilian invasion of US it was the naval planning AI which deemed the empty Caribbean to be a threat and wholly unknown terra incognita for us. They might've (and surely have) fixed some of the issues, but at least they were still there the last time I played. No cunning invasions and flankings, mainly invasions into Germany's heartland with two divisions. Or not patrolling the seas at all.  -Focus tree. These have been made for few bigger nations, making the game less flavoured (kinda like with the few portraits instead of proper pictures they used in the previous Hearts of Iron games). They also delay and derail some historical gameplay, as the focuses might delay Barbarossa quite a bit, for example. And most of the time they don't work with other ideologies, in case you have a civil war or a coup.  Now, I've enjoyed some of the games I've had so far, quite a lot even. But all these issues and the fact that game is much more arcade-y and simplified simply drive me away from it, and thus I cannot recommend it to anyone interested in the usual Paradox stuff with steep learning curves and lots of detail.

250 hours. After 250 hours I am starting to feel as if I have seen and done it all.  Hearts of Iron IV is the ultimate historical grand strategical simulation. As a fan of the series I can easily say this game is a huge improvement over it's predecessors.  The new political system is glorious. It's not really that realistic but it is very fun. It's easy to set up a scenario where you can test what would happen if your chosen country had a different form of government.  The way production works is really fun and realistic. You now have to produce a huge array of different equipment. It works really well, and when 1944 hits you really feel like your divisions have upgraded. When maybe in 1939 you had 3 panzer divisions with a few light tanks, you have heavy and fast panzer divisions in 1944 which can be three times as strong and effective. As the war drags on the casualties begin to stack up and it really feels like the world is at total war. Some games just ended in total destruction for all sides, while others are over quicker when good decisions are made.  Warfare feels more epic than ever. Especially naval and air combat are understandable and meaningful now. Never have I felt such an epic feeling of sending the imperial fleet on a daring mission to destroy the carriers of the USA.   The only thing I can complain about is the AI. It's quite easy to beat. Actually, really easy. But if you want a challanginge arcade game you should play something more like an arcade shooter. Hearts of Iron IV is purely about having fun with history and exploring interesting concepts and ideas. That said there are some things I don't like. For example, the AI makes really bad decisions regarding technology and production. Don't try playing on historical mode, because it doesn't work unless you are germany, japan, the ussr or the usa.  The extended modding capability of this game is great. I am really looking forward to the big ww1 mod, kaiserraich and maybe some funky or funny mods (I have already seen Trump and Anime mods, which are really fun).  I have a lot more to say about this game but if you find WW2 interesting you probably already know to get this game. Buy it now - it's cheap and fun!

Hearts of Iron 4 is an excellent strategy game. It does a good job of providing meaningful decisions in all aspects of the country (diplomacy, industry, research, military, etc.) without overwhelming you with options like its predecessor. The epidemic micromanagement has been replaced with useful tools such as the division templates. Army composition is important, so having the ability to quickly update entire forces is quite nice. Air combat and naval combat are also much more manageable now, with sea and air zones broken out into fairly large regions where you can assign missions to hundreds of ships and planes at a time to cover an area. (Fleets can be assigned to multiple regions, planes cannot, although they do seem to roam a bit outside of the region if they have the range and nothing to do inside.) Air superiority feels right in this game and has a strong effect and leaving your troops exposed to enemy close air support will almost always result in a loss. Supply makes much more sense than before and makes it so that the infrastructure damage to an area will slow down large armies quite a bit and weaken them significantly. Ports are often very important for getting supplies in and out of areas making naval superiority important as well. The damage caused to infrastructure by bombing can also be quite useful to stop the enemy's supply and destroying the factories keeping them equipped. Everything in this game just works together so well and feels like it has a purpose and that your actions actually change things without being too difficult to understand what is going on. I think this may be the best Paradox strategy yet, and definitely the one with the strongest and most complete gameplay at launch.

If you switch over you'll be producing something like 20 per day due to your factories not retaining as much efficiency.  So you need to decide. Do I start making the switch? And that's up to you! Each decision made must be thought through before executing, as one poor choice could set the player back months, or even end their campaign. Overall, I seriously recommend this game to anyong who enjoys Grand Strategy, WWII games, or any Paradox titles.

HOI4 is an excellent grand stratergy war game, which focuses largely on you being a commander and planning out your battle plans with a fantastic new battle planning system, not present in previous iterations of HOI. This is also supplemented by a fantsticly styled game, which even utilises the day, night and weather to effect combat conditions. However, this game has an array of problems with it...  Firstly, the AI... Now I know AI is difficult to program in the best of circumstances, but in games where AI is literally essential, it should be top priority, above all else. The AI for the most part is ok, but when it comes to naval invasions, creating armies and supply management, it completely fails. Most AI invasions are very small scale, and are usually if successful not followed up with any significant force to create a beach head. The AI also has a crappily made army creation and resource management system, it seems the AI follows the rule of creating enough resources to produce a specific type of division, and then completely ignores focusing on supplying that division with enough resources, instead it will then focus on producing more divisions of varying types creating ridiculos armies of 1500 divisions in some cases (for large countries such as USA), which is completely unessesary and causes alot of lag towards the end of the game, this also means that through prolonged fighting, most divisions will run out of supply and will capitulate before human players.  Secondly, replayability. This game's content is warfare on the same map, the only replayability is with different nations and different starting conditions. Making the game extremely repetitive after the first 20-30 hours after becoming familiar with most of the games mechanics.  However, despite these problems, I find it hard to deny that the game is fun in short campaigns every now and again, which is why I give HOI4 a 7/10.  TLDR; HOI4 Is a good grand strat war game, fantastic commanding ability, cons are poor AI for invasions, army creation, resource management, moderatly repetitive gameplay after 30 hours, final rating 7/10.

This game for me has been one of the best games that paradox has ever made and in my opinion is even better than CK2 EU4 and Stellaris. The UI can be a little tricky at first and the constuction and production screen can make a new players head spin, but once you get used to it its a peaice of cake to handle. The national focus idea is probally the single best feature in the game. All of the major 8 nations in the game get customized national focus trees. If you play a minor nation like sweeden or austria you get a genertic one but it is still great, For example on Franch's national focus tree you are givin the option to extend the Maginot Line or as Germany you could befriend poland instead of invade it. The national focus tree has so many options for each of the 8 major nations and the choices you make on it can determine weather or not WW2 happens and why it is fought for a completly diffrent gaming experience each and every time.  The division system has been signifigantly improved seince HOI3. It is alot less complitcated and now you only need 1 general or feild marshal rather than having to pick one for each and every division and army group. They have now made so that you can draw front lines and their corresponding offensive line. You can also draw fallback lines and the garrison tool which will make all selected armys go to the selected provinces and will gaurd the most important things in those areas suck as factories and oil refeneries. All of these features are now controlled by a amazinf AI that has been improved 1000% sense the last game and is now smarter with troops and better and making offensives happen like you want to. Also the game encourages you to use the AI as when you do each divison gets a 50% planning bonus which means that they will be better organized and they will attack and defend better than if you did it by hand. The diffrent skills for generals and feild marhsalls make a UGE diffrence when it comes to attacking and defending. For example a general can get traits like panzer leader or mountaineer which means that tanks attack better and go faster and all units are better in mountanious terrain. The same goes for feild marshalls as well.  The only bad things about the game are that the navy and planes need a little work. First of all the AI for it is very overwelming is unnassaryly complitcated. Also it can be made to select the diffrent naval and air bases respectaly they need to be bigger and more easly clickable.  In conclusion this game is one of the best games paradoz has made in years and I recomend that everyone buy it. However i must recomend the colonel version as it gives customized tanks and planes to all 8 major nations and it is really worth it.

Tentative reccomendation that I waited a while to write until I was sure what I wanted to say:  My very first Paradox game was HOI3, which I loved. It launched me into Ricky, Rome (briefly), CK (briefly), EU3, Vicky2, CK2, EU4, Stellaris, and a few other things along the way. Finally we've come full circle at HOI4.  I like it, the base game's a bit underwhelming as someone who played a lot of HOI3, but the core mechanics are pretty good and there's room to grow. I love the focus trees, which really serve to differentiate some of the major powers. I hope that, given time, we'll see plenty more of those for more interesting minors, but I understand that's already the plan. I really DO NOT like the simplified army-unit structure, I wish there were more layers of command structure, if not quite full HOI3-esque OOBs then something where I can see more actual leaders, because in all honesty I think having traits from your most senior commander affect individual units doesn't make sense since the actual leaders of those units probably would affect their behaviour more. I feel most of my complaints about the game center on this simplification of concepts present in HOI3, which admittedly was necessary since HOI3 was a beast to learn and master but even things like the 'triangle of leaning Axis/Allied/Comintern' that made a LOT of sense are gone.  All those complaints considered, WW2 strategy games like this are harder to make long-term interesting than CK2 or EU4 or Stellaris for a very important reason: Over centuries of gameplay, wars start and end, and nations go on to different concepts or challenges. But for a game solely focused on WW2, that can be hard because the war has to be very detailed while also being simple enough to understand, as once that war starts it's a brutal fight to the end. And despite my complaints, this constant slugging-match feeling is where the game shines. The new battle-plan style army management is a real gem, as are more extensive conscription/economic options. Allocation of factories to specific production lines, something abstracted with IC in HOI3, is fully fleshed out here and makes for a MUCH more detailed logistical game, which again was a major issue with HOI3. I absolutely love needing to shift factories from tanks to planes and having a major loss of efficiency, which slowly ramps back up, it's much more realistic and engaging thing and really makes you need to plan out your production better. I really like the new division designer, which again allows for really easy organizational changes to your units. The air and naval systems, while simplified, are VASTLY improved because it was a real pain to manage most of this in HOI3, I usually assigned them to a random AI-controlled HQ and let them take care of it.   All of the above, on the balance, makes this a game worth playing. I expect they'll add plenty of flavor, new mechanics, and more, and tweak some of the more annoying stuff. Currently, it seems to have less development support than CK2 or EU4, but I expect this to change as those games start to reach their final buildout (or at least I hope they are, both have had more expansions than I could easily count), and that resources are shifted. Some of the things I really think the game needs are an in-depth espionage system, a more detailed nuclear/secret-weapon system, a lot more flavor, smarter unit AI, a national-focus & stratetgic AI that doesn't make stupid choices (oh, Finland is part of the Allies in 1939, well I guess I still better declare war on it, said no Soviet Union ever) that negate your strategic or diplomatic brillancy. I'd also like to see an extended postgame or pregame, and better peace conferences (Yalta and others being negotiated BEFORE the war's end, and the ensuing horse trading). And finally, something introduced late in HOI3 that wasn't fully fleshed-out, a resistance system that ties down larger numbers of units in a garrison format, there are so many different ways that could go.  Tl;dr: Needs more work, but pretty good and will get better as it's a newborn and PDS will alter it dramatically over the next 2-3 years. 7/10 at present, I expect it to go up with time.

I am going to reference Hearts of Iron 3 a lot in this review, so if you haven't played that game some of what I say might not make a lot of sense.  I like the new production system, instead of building the divisions like in Hearts of Iron 3, you build the weapons for the divisions and then train the soldiers with the weapons. The efficiency bonuses for continuing to build the same thing instead of switching up are good too. Manpower is more realistic too, based on your total population instead of a constantly increasing value like in HoI3. Having caps for the industry in provinces makes sense too, although I will miss turning isolated islands into industrial power houses.  Ground combat has seen some improvements too, units that are being controlled by the AI can now be manually controlled when the AI is too stupid to do something. Amphibious invasions have to be planned, which is limiting from HoI3 but in a good way, in my opinion.  End of war diplomacy has seen a big improvement with the different winners taking turns cutting up pieces of the country instead of just holding whatever ridiculous pieces you happen to have walked troops through like in Hearts of Iron 3.  Now for some stuff I don't like. Air combat and naval combat is ridiculously simplified. Instead of assigning your air forces to attack a specific territory you have to assign them province level instructions and hope for the best. I know that in Hearts of Iron 3 it was a pain to be controlling each unit and assigning them to each territory but this is too simplified. The national focus trees are a great idea, but I feel like you can complete them too quickly and don't give enough divergent options. And why can't I design a new division template without war experience? Seems like a very arbitrary limit.  I'm sure there will be lots of changes to the game through patches and DLC to fix issues, but it is fun to play in its current form so I recommend it. However, if you already have Hearts of Iron 3 and are having fun with it, you might want to wait and pick up this one when it's on sale.

I did and do enjoy my time with the game, but thats because I was able to get used to a couple of terrible flaws of the game, that should actually be dealbreakers, and the only reason I powered through was because I was so hyped for the game.  Having gotten used to them, the game is fun, but for the first hours I was astonished at some of the bad decisions made in the making of this game, and to this day I'm struck by paradox not fixing them even though some really wouldnt be that hard to fix.  Looking at it plainly there are HUGE problems with the game, and to someone who's not already entirely sure that he loves the game I would not recommend it at it's current stage and the current speed of development.  The first flaw is the stuttering in mid-lategame which people with all kinds of hardware, including high-end, report, so its not my setup. The game can't handle its own troopcount and the lategame is a slideshow. (Though there's some people who report not having issues - either they are lying fanboys or the game just doesn't work well with some setups, nevermind the quality)  But this is optimization. I see that this will take a while to fix. What I can't understand are some design decisions that just baffle.  A) World Tension is garbage.  Neither does is make sense that Britain can only guarantee the Polish independence from Germany if non-Axis Japan declared war on China (wait, what...? How's that connected!?) or that I can only implement draftlaws after the Civil War in Spain is won by either side, But it also just doesnt work.  1. It means that Germany can take Poland/France/Anything right at the start of the game, because Allies can only intervene at some World Tension and it's too late then, so the first conquest is a freebee. 2. The game wanted to be more 'open' but due to world tension, all countries but the Axis, especially Britain and USA, are INCREADIBLY railroaded, as Britain theres literally one way of chosing your foci and until 100% worldtension all you do is guarantee countries.  B) The Ai is broken Both the 'Diplomatic/World AI' as the strategic AI are broken. The Diplomatic AI is completly useless. All alliances are preprogramed/set by fascist/democrat/commie so it literally does nothing but guarantee all countries with the same Ideology and at some point attack everything that isn't, and I think all 'attacks' are hardcoded. Countries that are at war with someone they are at war with will be asked to join that faction .It can be 'gamed' like crazy. Youre Germany and Want the Soviet Union and the Allies at war? Threaten Finland (i.e. fabricate a claim) before the Winter War. Allies will imidiatly guarantee it and, when the Soviet Union attacks it Allies and Soviets are at war. Thats just one example of dozens of rediculous decisions the AI will do because it doesn't 'think' or evaluate situations but just follows pre-programed instructions. Another would be that if as France or Britain you manage to stop Germany early and push on Berlin, Germany will still declare all kinds of wars.  The War-AI is just dumb. there's no other way of saying it. It's completly useless and the only reason why it can do ANYTHING is because your friendly frontline AI is also broken and constantly redeployes its units along the front, leaving all of them at 0-Strength. However, changes to the big picture, like 2nd fronts opening, naval invasions, shifts of power, sometimes even just the moon shining brighter than before will lead to the AI completly reorganizing, leaving its front basically defenseless, so its possible to defeat Germany as Denmark or Russia as Finlad.  And thats just normal 'front' battles for the AI. AI- Naval invasions are a joke, the Allies will lose Millions of Men in Invasions without ay sense, but they will annoy you like crazy as theres (still after the patch) pissweak invasions every couple of minutes (though admittedly less than before, but this is not OK! We just accept it because its better than it was before but its still ♥♥♥♥!). The AI itself does not defend adequatly against naval invasions, Britain can be taken without problem with 20 units. (Germany has about 200 when attacking France)  C) Half-Baked Ideas Theres so many great Ideas here but all executed terribly. For Example 1. Variants of Equipment. So if you have enough Battlefield Experience you can develop your Tank to be better so your Panzer IV gets better Armor and becomes the Panzer IV A or something like that. But the 'experience' is universal, so usually you will just save it and when researching a new Tank immidiatly make him 'Panzer IV Awesome' and forget it. 2. When researching a tank like the Panzer IV you can research variations of it like a Flak on its chassis or a Tankdestroyer or something. I have literally used this ONCE to try it. Theres no reason for it, because you can attach normal artillery, flak and anti-tank-guns to armored brigades without slowing them down, so why waste research, resources and production capabilities on this special version? Besides, theres no reason why you shouldnt just put 3 Tanks into the brigade instead of 1 Tank 1 TD 1 Artillery as the Stats of the Group are basically the same but the production is more complicated and you might run into not having one of the things, leaving your division weaker! 3. Bombing doesnt do damage to Units, but gives modifiers to Units fighting and all I can ask is 'why?'. If two armys oppose each other and I have absolut air supperiority, why cant I bomb them to destroy euipment, without charging their frontline?  4. Theres no peaceconference until the alliance is defeated. So if Germany helps Italy take Yugoslavia, it will end up with parts of that country until the USA, France, Britain and some other countries are defeated. 5. Naval Invasions aren't controlled directly but you pick a 'startport' and the place of invasion the units involved (with the max number depending on your techlevel) and then everything happens automatically after a while of preparation, if enough convoys are there, naval supremacy is achieved and the stars are aligned properly. Sounds like fun and works decently well on bigger invasions like England or something like that, where you plan one BIG thing, bring everything in order and after a while enjoy the show. But this is INCREADIBLY annoying when attacking Islands like in the Pacific or the mediterranean where you need to plan dozens of these invasions on barely-to-not-at-all-defended islands. 6. Rebels are not Units anymore but just destroy infastructure and factories and must be suppressed by HUNDREDS of Military Police Brigades. NOONE can look at this system and think 'jup. thats fun!' Its tedious! Its annoying! It's boring! It's just plain Work. 7. Trade is now fluent, so theres no Stockpile. If you buy more than you need, that is wasted IC, if you don't buy enough you get a huge hit on your production so thats also wasted IC. This means you must always and at all times be at the perfect 'buy' amount. The old system from HOI2/3 was bad, like always-put-it-on-AI-bad. But this worse! Since due to slowly increasing production and destruction or production of factorys your demand of any resource always changes, You will find yourself changing the imported amount almost daily! I've owned every version of HOI, and with some have bought multiple times (CD, Steam, etc). HOI was great. HOI 2 was also great. HOI 3 while providing a lot of new features seemed to just bog down. There was too much micro management. Now, don't get me wrong, sometimes I like micro managing everything but the trade off is that you will not get too far in the game.   For me starting with a country and building it up and then getting into WW2 was the thrill. But 3-4 years of building equipment, managing stuff, and waiting waiting waiting was sometimes too much. Maybe I have ADD. Actually I do.   So last few years like everyone I've been waiting for HOI4. I think that it finally got rid of a lot of micro management and allowed a player to get through the war faster... though that came with a price. The AI cedrtainly does a decent job, though in some places there needs to be tweaks. I suspect and expect that patches will be forthcoming to address that.   I like the way you can design units. Reminds me of Super Power game where you can design stuff and rename them. I like the battlefront system, though it is clunky at times.   I like and hate at the same time many of the message popups we used to get. I mean I could care less what Siam was doing if I was playing Germany or Italy.   In short, I recommend this game. It is a whole new experience in the long line of HOI games. There are going to be trade offs, and some diehard Grognards are not going to entirely like this new system/game. Then again, it may more accessible, portable down the road to other devices, and at least let you get through an entire war game in less than 30 hours.   But there are areas that need improvement. MODS are already on DAY ONE making a big difference. Tech trees are being expanded, additional photos added, etc. We may have had a more complete game in a year but then we would complain that it was taking another year... so again a good trade off. Get the game now, look for MODS and official patches and updates, as well as DLCs. Yeah we live in the world of DLCs, get over it.   Last on this review... if future patches can expand on the tech trees, add more of the 'missing' stuff, and bring back some of the HOI3 immersive features (even as something we can toggle on/off), then I think Paradox would have a more complete game and certainly appease many of the hard core gamers and naysayers. Finding that balance will be crucial. Some things now seem too easy, while others feel like something is missing, and others feel more difficult than they need to be.   Looking forward to new updates!! Now back to playing.

First of all let me say that I never write reviews. Secondly, for Hearts of Iron 4, I was torn between writing a positive review or a negative review.   1. Hearts of Iron 4 differs from it predecessor game in both it's increase in depth (believe it or not since everyone complained about the difficulty of Hearts of Iron 3) but also it's streamlined capability which enhances it playability. Futhermore, HOI4 can factor in such variables as Hiltler's Great Panzer Heist (a good book to read) which makes it possible for units to be made up of a variety of models of the same equipment. That has been sorely missed in previous wargames (at least in a transparent way) and this mix of models proved to be a great problem for the Third Reich due to the huge maintenance complexity issues which arose for that country. Other countries also had this problem but Nazi Germany took it to an extreme.  2. Back to HOI4s main problem: The lack of an extensive sequential manual for the game means that the gamer must wade through a number of YouTube videos just to sort through this problem. Probably the best YouTube videos for this game come from Praetorian HiJynx. Anyway, this increases the game learning curve for most of us. It seems almost implausable that Paradox Interactive would work on a game for 3 years and not include an extensive manual. And yet that's exactly what they did which diminished their wonderful product. As a note, the Wiki that comes with the game doesn't even approach a real manual.  3. As further deeper insight into this problem, it is rumored that Paradox will float an IPO soon (stock market.) From past experience, I know that this is often the death knell for a company as far as excellence is concerned because corporations then are forced to focus on profit and not competency. Since I have seen what I consider some very poor marketing tactics used by Paradox nickeling and diming gamers to be sure (to be fair here, many companies are using these same tactics), then I certainly hope that the company is not headed in that direction. Especially Paradox who has a unique niche in grand strategy games. But who can say.  4. My final point is clear: PARADOX, GIVE US A COMPREHENSIVE MANUAL. At least something so we can see how all your game components are interacting with one another. It would be nice if as in the past, the manual had reference to strategy and tactics but we at least need the basics or we'll have to sort through a lot of garbage to learn the game like I did. Do whatever you want and just have fun because it is an awsome game which should get even better with time. Paradox supports it's titles for many years, adding lot's of new content and improving what's already been realased.   I will agree with most of the reviews about poor AI. But truthfully speaking, which game of a scale that big has good AI? I'am afraid there isn't one. IMHO the AI is the weakest element of almost every video game regardless of the genre. And doing a good AI in a strategy game is even more difficult. I choose to accept that. The game is still tons of fun!

A highly-detailed strategy game, which gives you many options to meet your targets. The balance between historical facts and the player freedom to step away from them, was probably the most challenging bit for the developers. So, it's not the game to completely rewrite the history in your sense but since you can take control over many different countries and their specific histories, it still offers enough room to be creative. During gameplay, you must find the right balance between politics, diplomacy, research, recruitment, and production. The tech-tree gives you many options to develop the right combination of gear to supply your troops with. In my opinion the options for diplomacy could be a bit more versatile but I assume that's also down to the fact that it has to follow certain historical facts. It's the first game out of the HoI-series that I have played so I can't compare it to previous versions. This game requires a lot of time to be played properly but if you have some nights to spare and want to get into the position of a leader during WWII it's your choice.

If you want to have the full graphical experience, you should make sure you got a computer that can handle the game. But if you have a lower-end one, just lowering the settings will be fine.  TL;DR: a very nice paradox game. buy it
